title: This start-up wants to change how you eat lunch
text:
Clare Leighton, DishDash country manager for Australia, said there had also been a push by many employees in those workplaces around sustainability, and DishDash worked closely with meal producers to have minimal packaging.

The company had seen a gap in the market for a well-managed, reliable service of providing meals to companies, but didn't own any delivery trucks or kitchens itself.

It used outside providers and delivery firms, and with its advanced technology was able to make it seamless with one ''dashboard'' overseeing the whole system.

Companies were happy to outsource the provision of meals to a specialist, rather than wrestle with caterers and other delivery avenues themselves.

The time-saving aspect was also important for technology workers.

"A lot of the time they are tied to their desks in a tech kind of role,'' Ms Leighton said.

Mr Schneider said the direct-to-consumer segment was fiercely competitive with dozens of home meal kits groups and other delivery companies battling it out. Supermarket giant Woolworths in July took a stake in home meal kits group Marley Spoon, giving it extra grunt in a race against rivals such as HelloFresh.

Advertisement

But the business-to-business sector had been under-utilised, and the rising focus on health and well-being had been a strong catalyst.

"Healthy food has helped us gain a lot of traction,'' he said. Investors in the start-up in Singapore had included executives from Amazon, Netflix, Airbnb and Dell.

He said the Sydney operations of DishDash had reached a break-even point after 10 months, while in Melbourne it was even faster at seven months.

The company is set to raise $US6 million ($8.8 million) to help fund expansion to other cities like Dublin, London, Tokyo and Hong Kong.

He said the company was closely scrutinising the volatile situation in Hong Kong where pro-democracy protesters and police have been clashing for months.

"We're monitoring the situation obviously,'' Mr Schneider said.

The company was also eyeing expansion in Brisbane, Adelaide and Perth.

Some of the expansion plans had been driven by international and national companies wanting to offer the same service to employees in other cities of their national networks.
description: A corporate food business with blue-chip clients like Google, Uber and BCG is raising $9m to fuel offshore expansion.
